{{citation style|date=June 2011}} {{Jews by country}} [[Jew]]s have lived in France since [[Roman Empire|Roman]] times, with a [[History of the Jews in France|rich and complex history]]. In the Middle Ages, French kings expelled most of the original [[Ashkenazi Jews|Askhenazi]] Jewish population to Germany. Since the [[French Revolution]] (and [[Jewish Emancipation|Emancipation]]), Jews have been able to contribute to all aspects of French culture and society. Moreover, the [[Adolphe CrÃ©mieux#Cremieux decree|Cremieux decree]] gave in 1870 the full French citizenship to Jews, mostly [[Sephardi|Sephardi Jews]], living in Maghreb under [[French colonization]]. During World War II, a significant number of Jews living in [[Metropolitan France]] perished in [[the Holocaust]], deported to [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[death camps]] by the [[Vichy France|French Vichy]] government. After 1945, France served as a haven for [[Ashkenazi Jews|Askhenazi]] [[refugees]], then after the independence of [[History_of_Morocco#Independence_in_1956|Morocco]], [[History_of_French_era_Tunisia#Independence|Tunisia]] and the end of [[Algerian War]], an influx of immigration of Sephardi Jews saw the Jewish population triple to around 600,000, making it the largest Jewish community in Western Europe. Behind the United States and Israel, France ranks 3rd by Jewish population. In 2008, the Jewish Agency evaluated the Jewish population in France to be 488,000,<ref>[http://www.jpppi.org.il/JPPPI/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=111&FID=341&PID=586 The Jewish Agency Assessment 2008]</ref> not mentioning French citizens with only one Jewish parent or grandparent.
The following is a list of some prominent Jews and people of Jewish origins,<ref>As a particular counter-example, current French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] had a Jewish grandfather, is officially Catholic and is not part of this list.</ref> among others, (not all of them practice, or practiced, the Jewish religion) who were born in, or are very strongly associated with, France. The [[French nationality law]] itself, strongly secular, forbides any statistics or lists based on ethnic membership.<ref>{{fr}}[http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/francais/les-decisions/depuis-1958/decisions-par-date/2007/2007-557-dc/decision-n-2007-557-dc-du-15-novembre-2007.1183.html DÃ©cision nÂ° 2007-557 DC du 15 novembre 2007 ] ''Conseil Constitutionnel'', 2007-11-15</ref>
